height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 02 Nov 2020 22:59:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f8f01b39e9fe4001900a567?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"bfce47189200e09445a6168b7dcf0ae7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn8@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-35-341_1b78a2d951d29558.webp","destWidth":910,"destHeight":683,"sourceBytes":41828,"destBytes":41828,"author":"oseddiq@insider.com (Oma Seddiq)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f8f01b0c21cfb001946901c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn65@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-58-487_be52a68bf967b77a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-293_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=11lpJXm90K8:Vn428jCCDWw:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn98@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-54-338_5033ef1f2af7bbf3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=11lpJXm90K8:Vn428jCCDWw:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn72@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-57-731_fb1b1c8d7f4d1cc1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=11lpJXm90K8:Vn428jCCDWw:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn46@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-47-879_d65a9c1081463490.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/11lpJXm90K8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn97@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-58-440_d44442ff26b4c31f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604381490450},{"createdTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"How Biden's coronavirus plan compares to Trump's actions, in one point-by-point chart","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-biden-coronavirus-plan-compares-to-trump-strategy-economy-testing-2020-10","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f74a14c0ab50d00184ad448?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump biden debate\" height=\"3587\" width=\"5380\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Donald Trump and Joe Biden participate in the first presidential debate at Case Western Reserve University on September 29, 2020. Chris Wallace moderates.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jim Watson/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The pandemic <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-campaign-attacks-joe-biden-not-having-coronavirus-fox-news-2020-10\">is center stage</a> in the race between President Donald Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden.</li>\n<li>Nearly 100 million ballots have already been cast ahead of Tuesday's presidential election.</li>\n<li>Here's how Biden's proposed coronavirus strategy compares to Trump's actions, point by point.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Many Americans have already voted on who they want to lead the US's coronavirus response next year. Nearly 100 million ballots have been cast ahead of Tuesday's presidential election — more than two-thirds of the total ballots cast in 2016.</p><p>President Donald Trump's handling of the pandemic is, of course, a key issue for voters. Although vaccine development is racing ahead and the US has significantly ramped up testing since the spring, the administration was initially painfully slow to distribute tests and personal protective equipment.</p><p>Trump has also been criticized for ignoring and contradicting top public-health experts. The president has suggested that masks are voluntary and erroneously blames increased testing for the US's high case count. His administration at one point even updated guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to suggest that <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/cdc-coronavirus-asymptomatic-testing-advice-change-2020-9\">testing asymptomatic people wasn't necessary</a>, despite knowledge that asymptomatic individuals fuel transmission.</p><p>Biden, by contrast, emphasizes his desire to let scientists lead the federal coronavirus response. He has championed mask wearing and promised to further expand contact tracing and at-home testing.</p><p>Biden and Trump agree on many points, though, including that a vaccine should be free for all Americans. Biden also plans to set aside emergency funding for K-12 education and loans for small businesses during the pandemic — actions Trump has already taken.</p><p>Here's a rundown of how <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-coronavirus-plan-needs-strategy-to-unite-country-2020-9\">Biden's coronavirus plan</a> compares to Trump's actions so far:</p><div class=\"insider-raw-embed\"><iframe title=\"COVID-19 response\" aria-label=\"chart\" id=\"datawrapper-chart-TxaTe\" src=\"https://datawrapper.dwcdn.net/TxaTe/1/\" scrolling=\"no\" frameborder=\"0\" style=\"width: 0; min-width: 100% ; border: none;\" height=\"763\"></iframe><script type=\"text/javascript\">!function(){\"use strict\";window.addEventListener(\"message\",(function(a){if(void 0!==a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"])for(var e in a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"]){var t=document.getElementById(\"datawrapper-chart-\"+e)||document.querySelector(\"iframe[src*='\"+e+\"']\");t&&(t.style.height=a.data[\"datawrapper-height\"][e]+\"px\")}}))}();</script></div><h2>'The devil is in the details'</h2><p>Vice President Mike Pence highlighted the similarities between Trump's and Biden's coronavirus plans at the vice presidential debate last month.</p><p>\"When you look at the Biden plan, it reads an awful lot like what President Trump and I and our task force have been doing every step of the way,\" Pence said. \"And quite frankly, when I look at their plan that talks about advancing testing, creating new PPE, developing the vaccine — it looks a little bit like plagiarism.\"</p><p>The candidates do share several important priorities, but public-health experts say they differ in their execution strategies.</p><p>\"The devil is in the details,\" Dr. Leana Wen, a public-health professor at George Washington University, told Business Insider. For example, she said, \"it's not just a matter of the right to get a test — it's also the ability to get a test.\"</p><p>Experts say Trump's aggressive push to reopen schools and downplay the threat of the virus contradicted science-based guidance, including the White House's own safety criteria.</p><p>\"A lot of people agreed those [criteria] were very good, but the confusion was that, in my opinion, there wasn't a clear message from the top once those were directed. And, in fact, Trump himself seemed to undermine them,\" Marissa Levine, a public-health professor at the University of South Florida, told Business Insider.</p><p>That's part of the reason why Biden has accused Trump of having \"no plan\" to lead the country out of the pandemic.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f77da522400440019129cec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump day US President Donald Trump departs a rally at Dayton International Airport in Dayton, Ohio September 21, 2020. (Photo by MANDEL NGAN / AFP) (Photo by MANDEL NGAN/AFP via Getty Images)\" height=\"681\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mandel Ngan/AFP/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Pence, meanwhile, has criticized Biden's proposed strategy as \"a government takeover of healthcare,\" but experts say that isn't correct.</p><p>\"It would be inaccurate to characterize the Biden approach as top-down and the Trump approach as empowering local authorities. Actually, it's the opposite,\" Wen said. \"What you really need is to empower the locals to do their work, but you only do that by having the federal government provide the resources to do so.\"</p><h2>A clash over testing strategies</h2><p>The US has now tested more people per capita than most countries: around 370 out of every 100,000 people. But the Trump administration adopted a piecemeal approach to testing, leaving it to states to create testing plans. The consequence, experts say, is that states are pitted against each other for the same supply of tests.</p><p>\"My former colleagues in all parts of the country are saying that they don't have access to enough tests, and enough rapid tests,\" Wen said in September. \"The federal government is the one that should be using its purchasing power to procure these tests and to make them available to locals.\"</p><p>Biden has pledged to set up at least 10 mobile testing sites and drive-through facilities per state. He has also proposed a program to scale up test manufacturing, similar to what the Trump administration has done for vaccine development.</p><p>Trump's Operation Warp Speed program is currently manufacturing vaccine doses in large quantities while clinical trials are ongoing. Experts say that's a strong element of his coronavirus strategy.&#160;</p><p>\"That's in general a good program and a good approach to this vaccine development process,\" Dr. Amesh Adalja, a senior scholar at the Johns Hopkins University Center for Health Security, told Business Insider in August.</p><h2>Diverging approaches to economic relief&#160;</h2><p>One-third of voters surveyed in <a href=\"https://www.kff.org/coronavirus-covid-19/report/kff-health-tracking-poll-september-2020/\">a September poll</a> by the Kaiser Family Foundation said the economy would be the most important issue in deciding their vote for president. The coronavirus came second, with 20% of those surveyed saying the pandemic was most important. However, that poll happened before Trump <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-coronavirus-treatments-prognosis-puzzle-doctors-remdesivir-dexamethasone-2020-10\">was hospitalized with the virus</a> and before the US's record-breaking third surge in cases.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f7ef347282c500018c7947f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Joe Biden\" height=\"799\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Experts say economic recovery is deeply intertwined with the nation's ability to curb the virus' spread.</p><p>\"We can't solve the business crisis unless we solve the health crisis first,\" Howard Koh, a professor at the Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health, told Business Insider in July.&#160;\"Every business is in the health business, whether they realize it or not, because they're taking care of their employees, their customers, their communities, and the environment.\"</p><p>Both candidates have pledged additional relief funding for small businesses and individual Americans.</p><p>In addition to federal stimulus money, Biden's economic recovery plan includes an emergency fund for state and local governments. The money could go toward cash payments or tax relief for vulnerable individuals, as well as interest-free loans for small- and medium-sized businesses.</p><p>The Trump administration has already delivered <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-economy-factbox/trump-biden-offer-clashing-visions-on-reopening-economy-idUSKBN2681FW\">$3.4 trillion in stimulus aid</a> to local governments, businesses, and individuals. But a second round of stimulus checks did not appear before Election Day.</p><p><em>This story has been updated with new information. It was originally published October 9, 2020.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/how-biden-coronavirus-plan-compares-to-trump-strategy-economy-testing-2020-10'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a (Aria Bendix)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f74a14c0ab50d00184ad448?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn20@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-42-641_3df2769477ed693a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f77da522400440019129cec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-34-514_3e04774211a82180.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f7ef347282c500018c7947f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn49@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-53-263_eaf2d69df5b81e02.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-293_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DN3i_AHxfxc:xVz6YSejFBY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn87@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-48-225_6d11092eace97017.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DN3i_AHxfxc:xVz6YSejFBY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn8@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-49-409_cf7a9fa4310c215e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=DN3i_AHxfxc:xVz6YSejFBY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn26@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-54-567_1a223a9305b673c5.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/DN3i_AHxfxc":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604381490539},{"createdTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"Astronauts on the space station see vibrant deserts, roiling storms, and volcanic eruptions. These are the best photos ever taken from the ISS.","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/27-best-space-station-photos-show-earth-hidden-beauty-2019-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd867e8fd9db262e40affa7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"astronauts spacewalk international space station iss\" height=\"1524\" width=\"2032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Backdropped by New Zealand and the Cook Strait in the Pacific Ocean, astronauts Robert Curbeam (left) and Christer Fuglesang (right) participate in an extravehicular activity.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/content/space-station-photo-highlights/#lowerAccordion-set1-slide9\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Astronauts have lived on the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-astronauts-connect-spacex-crew-dragon-spaceship-international-space-station-2020-5\">International Space Station</a> continuously for 20 years &#8212; the first expedition arrived on November 2, 2000.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-astronauts-doug-hurley-bob-behnken-biography-spacex-demo2-2020-5\">Astronauts</a> have taken millions of pictures of their <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/overview-effect-nasa-apollo8-perspective-awareness-space-2015-8\">breathtaking views</a> throughout those two decades, capturing from sprawling city lights to volcanic eruptions.</li>\n<li>Here are the 27 best photos ever taken from the ISS.&#160;</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The first expedition to the International Space Station reached the orbiting laboratory on November 2, 2000 — exactly 20 years ago. Since then, not a day has gone by without astronauts zipping through space.</p><p>That's the longest-lasting human presence ever in space. In the last two decades, the people living on the ISS have taken millions of photos. The views can sometimes be hard to believe.</p><p>\"How can something so beautiful be tolerated by human eyes?\" NASA astronaut Mike Massimino told the <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2019/national/50-astronauts-life-in-space/\">Washington Post</a>.</p><p>Here are 27 of the best photos ever taken from the space station.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe ISS has been orbiting Earth for nearly 22 years. Its first module launched into orbit on November 20, 1998.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd70496fd9db226981ff4e2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"spacewalk international space station cosmonaut Sergey Ryazanskiy\" height=\"1275\" width=\"1701\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Russian cosmonaut Sergey Ryazanskiy takes a break during a six-hour spacewalk on the International Space Station, August 22, 2013.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/details-iss037e028789\" target=\"_blank\">Johnson Space Center</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAfter the first crew of astronauts arrived on November 2, 2000, they started snapping photos.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd6ff74fd9db221aa1d4cb4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"chile river glaciated iss\" height=\"1533\" width=\"2044\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A glaciated area at the headwaters of the Rio de la Colonia in southern Chile, December 2000.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://spaceflight.nasa.gov/gallery/images/station/crew-1/html/iss01e5107.html\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tAstronauts have been capturing their breathtaking views from space ever since. They've taken millions of photos.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd7187ffd9db23a62092a94?format=jpeg\" alt=\"lake powell grand staircase escalante iss\" height=\"1465\" width=\"1954\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Nearly the full length of Lake Powell, a reservoir on the Colorado River, in the Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument, September 6, 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/lake-powell-and-grand-staircase-escalante\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/facts-and-figures\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tUsually, about six people live and work together in the station, orbiting Earth every 90 minutes.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd723bcfd9db23ac71a5fe5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"venice lagoon iss\" height=\"960\" width=\"1440\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A narrow barrier island protects the Lagoon of Venice from storm waves in the northern Adriatic Sea, May 9, 2014.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/83793/venice-lagoon?src=ve\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/facts-and-figures\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tThat means they see 16 sunrises and sunsets every day.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd71a62fd9db23b0822f85c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sunrise iss\" height=\"1464\" width=\"1952\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Scott Kelly posted this photo to Twitter on March 1, 2016, writing &#34;Rise and shine! My last #sunrise from space then I gotta go! 1 of 5. #GoodMorning from @space_station! #YearInSpace.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/last-sunrise-from-a-year-in-space\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/facts-and-figures\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tToday, the ISS orbits about 250 miles above Earth.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd710b3fd9db233c9130af6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"pacific ocean iss\" height=\"2768\" width=\"4928\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The sun&#39;s glint reflects off the Pacific Ocean shadowed by a line of cumulonimbus clouds, July 20, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/the-suns-glint-reflects-off-the-pacific-ocean\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe astronauts inside don't always know or share much detail about the sights they see. But many say they never get bored with the views.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd864dbfd9db25f6a191338?format=jpeg\" alt=\"22208561922_8e23e6d74d_h\" height=\"1067\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Scott Kelly posted this photo of Australia taken from the International Space Station on Twitter with the caption, &#34;#EarthArt A single pass over the #Australian continent. Picture 15 of 17. #YearInSpace.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasa2explore/22208561922/in/album-72157659515819800/\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"I'm not sure I'd want to be in the same room with someone who could get tired of that,\" astronaut Kathy Sullivan told National Geographic.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd71d70fd9db239633ffad4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"iran desert iss\" height=\"1275\" width=\"1701\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>As the space station passed over the deserts of Iran, a crew member caught this unusual geological pattern, February 14, 2014. When wind erodes layers of rock that have folded together over time, it exposes the shape and color of the folds.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://images.nasa.gov/details-iss038e047388.html\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JSC</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nationalgeographic.com/magazine/2018/03/astronauts-space-earth-perspective/\">National Geographic</a></em></p>\n\tSome of the most colorful photos came from astronaut Scott Kelly, who shared many of his favorite views on social media.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd6ff5afd9db223dc400155?format=jpeg\" alt=\"france coast iss\" height=\"1065\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scott Kelly posted this photo of the Mediterranean coast of France taken from the International Space Station on Instagram, March 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/color-palette-of-the-french-coast\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tFrom 2015 to 2016, Kelly spent 340 consecutive days on the space station. It was the longest single human spaceflight ever.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd70a5ffd9db22ffa3bb573?format=jpeg\" alt=\"japan from space night iss\" height=\"1368\" width=\"1824\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scott Kelly posted this photo to Twitter on July 25, 2015 with the caption, &#34;#Goodevening #Japan. Showing @Astro_Kimiya how to take pictures of #Earth at night. #YearInSpace.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasa2explore/20882011641/in/album-72157658205964848/\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-station-astronaut-record-holders\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tWhen they fly over cities, astronauts can see details from above, like these colored salt ponds in Sfax, Tunisia.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd70d33fd9db232f452b91e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"sfax tunisia iss\" height=\"1368\" width=\"1824\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Brilliantly colored salt ponds south of Tunisia&#39;s port city of Sfax, June 19, 2015.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasa2explore/24028311665/in/album-72157662199333789/\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOn cloudless nights, some views are even more clear. They call Paris \"the city of lights\" for a reason.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd71ba2fd9db23b75763723?format=jpeg\" alt=\"paris night iss\" height=\"2300\" width=\"1531\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Around midnight local time on April 8, 2015, astronauts aboard the International Space Station took this photograph of Paris.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/paris-at-night\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tSometimes the clouds themselves make beautiful shapes. Astronauts can watch big storms from above.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd70d7dfd9db23069740244?format=jpeg\" alt=\"thunderstorm iss\" height=\"1368\" width=\"1824\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Thunderstorms roll over the South China Sea, July 29, 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasa2explore/31730865946/in/album-72157674260752223/\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThey can even peer into the eyes of hurricanes.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd6ff5afd9db22170424713?format=jpeg\" alt=\"hurricane eye dorian iss\" height=\"1364\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Nick Hague posted this photograph of Hurricane Dorian to Twitter on Sept. 2, 2019. He wrote, &#34;You can feel the power of the storm when you stare into its eye from above.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/hurricane-dorians-eye-seen-from-the-international-space-station\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Nick Hague</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tWhen the Caribbean isn't plagued by cyclones, the Bahamas are a calm blue oasis from an astronaut's perspective.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd7001ffd9db222003559f9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"bahamas iss\" height=\"1065\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scott Kelly shared this picture of the Bahamas taken from the International Space Station on Twitter on July 19, 2015 with the caption, &#34;#Bahamas, the strokes of your watercolors are always a refreshing sight. #YearInSpace.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/bahamas-the-strokes-of-your-watercolors-are-always-a-refreshing-sight\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThis frozen lake in the Himalayas reveals a different kind of blue oasis.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd6ff5afd9db221595698f7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"himalayan lake iss\" height=\"1065\" width=\"1600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scott Kelly posted this photo on Twitter with the caption, &#34;Cool frozen lake in #Himalayas! #YearInSpace,&#34; January 6, 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/cool-frozen-lake-in-himalayas\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe views aren't always calming, though. Volcano eruptions are easy to see from space as well.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd724eafd9db23b1624ea12?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Raikoke Volcano eruption iss\" height=\"1150\" width=\"1533\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>On the morning of June 22, 2019, astronauts on the ISS captured the plume of ash and gases rising from the erupting Raikoke Volcano on the Kuril Islands in the North Pacific.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/145226/raikoke-erupts\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"Not many artists in this world are as creative as Mother Nature,\" ISS commander Alexander Gerst told NASA about this image.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd7264efd9db23b4d0494a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"africa coast iss\" height=\"1366\" width=\"1821\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The west coast of southern Africa, photographed from the ISS, April 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/the-creativity-of-mother-nature\" target=\"_blank\">ESA/NASA-A.Gerst</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/the-creativity-of-mother-nature\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tThe aurora borealis is one of nature's most fascinating artworks. It appears when electrically charged particles from the sun collide with oxygen and nitrogen in Earth's atmosphere.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd876aafd9db266bd0ef9c6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora borealis iss\" height=\"1531\" width=\"2300\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The aurora borealis, or the &#34;northern lights,&#34; over Canada as seen from the space station near the highest point of its orbital path, September 15, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://eol.jsc.nasa.gov/SearchPhotos/photo.pl?mission=ISS053&#38;roll=E&#38;frame=23915\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/JSC</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://pwg.gsfc.nasa.gov/polar/EPO/auroral_poster/aurora_all.pdf\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tAstronauts and cosmonauts on the ISS can see the same phenomenon on the other side of the globe, too — the aurora australis.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd71ec5fd9db239bd00e6e8?format=jpeg\" alt=\"aurora australis nasa space station ex52 june 25 2017\" height=\"944\" width=\"1259\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The aurora australis on June 25, 2017, as seen from the International Space Station.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/videos/index.html\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tHuman activities can look artistic from above as well, like this launch of a Russian spacecraft.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd7111cfd9db236ab412f97?format=jpeg\" alt=\"soyuz launch iss\" height=\"961\" width=\"1281\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>From aboard the International Space Station, astronaut Christina Koch photographed the Soyuz MS-15 spacecraft ascending into space after its launch from Kazakhstan on September 25, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/viewing-a-launch-from-above\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Christina Koch</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tVery few people have enjoyed these views: 241 people from 19 countries have visited the ISS.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd71e80fd9db23c3c077444?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mecca seen from an International Space Station.\" height=\"1336\" width=\"1781\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Scott Kelly posted this photo taken from the space station to Twitter on September 23, 2015 with the caption, &#34;#GoodMorning to the Holy City of #Mecca #Makkah! #YearInSpace&#34;.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:ISS-44_Mecca,_Saudi_Arabia.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Scott Kelly / NASA / Wikimedia</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/feature/facts-and-figures\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tAstronauts have conducted 231 spacewalks since the station opened.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd6ffcafd9db22439093b44?format=jpeg\" alt=\"astronauts spacewalk international space station iss\" height=\"1522\" width=\"2030\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Backdropped by New Zealand and the Cook Strait in the Pacific Ocean, astronauts Robert Curbeam (left) and Christer Fuglesang (right) participate in an extravehicular activity, December 12, 2006.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/content/space-station-photo-highlights/#lowerAccordion-set1-slide9\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/spacewalks/\">NASA</a></em></p>\n\tSometimes that's when they get the best vistas.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd72148fd9db23a33519b42?format=jpeg\" alt=\"astronaut spacewalk iss\" height=\"1368\" width=\"1824\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Thomas Pesquet conducts a spacewalk 259 miles above Argentina on January 13, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasa2explore/32303169771/in/album-72157657170189075/\" target=\"_blank\">ESA/NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBehind them: the vacuum of space.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd70e2ffd9db2312c5f11b5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"astronaut spacewalk iss\" height=\"1467\" width=\"1956\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Luca Parmitano conducts a spacewalk on November 15, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/spacewalker-luca-parmitano-rides-the-canadarm2-robotic-arm-0\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBut even that void sometimes offers beautiful views.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd70eacfd9db231c7034123?format=jpeg\" alt=\"milky way iss\" height=\"1065\" width=\"1420\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Astronaut Scott Kelly posted this photo to Twitter on August 9, 2015 with the caption, &#34;Day 135. #MilkyWay. You&#39;re old, dusty, gassy and warped. But beautiful. Good night from @space_station! #YearInSpace&#34;.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/milkyway-youre-old-dusty-gassy-and-warped\" target=\"_blank\">NASA/Scott Kelly</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\t\"Orbiting Earth in the spaceship, I saw for the first time how beautiful our planet is,\" Yuri Gagarin, the first human in space, said in 1961. \"Let us preserve and increase this beauty, and not destroy it.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5dd71337fd9db237db564317?format=jpeg\" alt=\"cloud patterns iss\" height=\"1467\" width=\"1956\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The International Space Station was 257 miles above the North Pacific Ocean when a crew member photographed these cloud patterns south of the Aleutian Islands, April 28, 2019.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.nasa.gov/image-feature/cloud-patterns-south-of-the-aleutian-islands\" target=\"_blank\">NASA</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/unesco/posts/when-i-orbited-the-earth-in-a-spaceship-i-saw-for-the-first-time-how-beautiful-o/10156330912838390/\">UNESCO</a></em></p>\n</div><div /5dd71ba2fd9db23b75763723?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn42@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-55-873_185458726b87f7b4.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd70d7dfd9db23069740244?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn4@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-50-203_09ff396bc328839e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd6ff5afd9db22170424713?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn36@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-45-158_662737a1d64949b6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd7001ffd9db222003559f9?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn93@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-52-921_7ae17768a2523335.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd6ff5afd9db221595698f7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn98@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-52-946_e4382de81992a129.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd724eafd9db23b1624ea12?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn72@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-43-554_b6dc67e06ecf6c28.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd7264efd9db23b4d0494a2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn30@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-35-885_58f2e0680ab23aab.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd876aafd9db266bd0ef9c6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn82@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-46-418_367d99d6bc4da32c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd71ec5fd9db239bd00e6e8?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn63@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-38-292_28ef98349e0b52cf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd7111cfd9db236ab412f97?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn13@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-57-214_195acb8e981979bb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd71e80fd9db23c3c077444?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-37-916_bdb8dab56a0fddea.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd6ffcafd9db22439093b44?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn71@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-39-323_88e51ff08fbc57e5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd72148fd9db23a33519b42?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn20@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-37-885_c3e08fdd6be94b1a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd70e2ffd9db2312c5f11b5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn74@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-36-523_df2e39be948cd065.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd70eacfd9db231c7034123?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn53@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-52-304_7ff1ebf51b3da594.webp","https://i.insider.com/5dd71337fd9db237db564317?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn63@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-39-092_be48380d337aa73c.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-293_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=xbigSfeG1S0:i1O5JGXOkiY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn66@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-58-820_e78c8993c9fe3874.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=xbigSfeG1S0:i1O5JGXOkiY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn91@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-42-430_0ebaf7b2ba8c3a10.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=xbigSfeG1S0:i1O5JGXOkiY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn62@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-34-417_2fa7538d7d613a31.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/xbigSfeG1S0":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn16@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-39-525_57339b3400419962.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604381490593},{"createdTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"Why the M240 is the US military's best machine gun","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/why-the-m240-is-the-us-militarys-best-machine-gun-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa061e56f5b310011724e74?format=jpeg\" alt=\"M240B marines\" height=\"750\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Marine Corps</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>The M240 machine gun entered service with the US military in 1977, and several variants have been introduced since then.</li>\n<li>The M240's reliability, accuracy, and easy operational use are what distinguish it from the military's other machine guns, writes Jonathan Weiss, a former Navy SWCC and Special Operations Combat Medic.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>The American military has seen heavy weapons come and go. Yet, some seem perennial. The M240 machine gun is one of those weapons that have stood the test of time.</p><p>Weighing in at about 30 pounds, with a rate of fire ranging from 650 to 950 rounds per minute, the M240 can throw out a wall of lead and undoubtedly wreak havoc on those on the receiving end.</p><p>The M240 came into service with the US military in 1977 and over the years, several variants have been developed. The M240 is an open bolt, gas-operated weapon, and shoots a 7.62 mm x 51 mm NATO round.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa0657569331a0011bc6ceb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Navy aircraft carrier Nimitz M240\" height=\"1664\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Master-at-Arms 2nd Class Alexander Tamarak fires an M240 machine gun during a live-fire training exercise aboard aircraft carrier USS Nimitz in the Pacific Ocean, June 24, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Navy/MCS 2nd Class Elesia K. Patten</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>It often serves as <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M240_machine_gun\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a crew-served weapon</a>. It is commonly being mounted on boats, trucks, and aircraft, but can also be carried in the field and mounted on a bipod or tripod. The M240 is built by FN America, a subsidiary of FN Herstal.</p><p>The M240 has served in every major combat conflict since its inception. It has undoubtedly proved its worth for the Unites States and foreign militaries.</p><p>Generally speaking, the US utilizes three different heavy weapons platforms: the M2 Browning .50 caliber machine gun, the Gau-17 Minigun, and the M240. Each weapon has its role and purpose and excels in certain environments.</p><p>The M2 Browning .50 cals are obviously cool and sling a huge round that can pierce armor and literally destroy anything it comes in contact with. But these benefits come with a price.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa065786f5b310011724e80?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Army UH-60 Black Hawk helicopter M240\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Spc. Alexander Haase, a crew chief, secures his M240 machine gun on a UH-60 Black Hawk, October 19, 2016.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army/Capt. Adan Cazarez</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>First, the weapon system is huge, and changing out a hot barrel in the dark sucks — there's just no other way to say it. Newer versions have corrected this issue, but historically, the weapons had to be head spaced and timed after putting a new barrel on, which is also a huge pain. Lastly, I've seen these weapons jam more than I'm comfortable with.</p><p>The Gau-17 Minigun is about as badass as it gets, but it has its limitations. For one, it requires electrical power, which creates obvious barriers. Additionally, when it jams, it typically jams hard and cannot be easily cleared. It is a very high-maintenance weapon that is no fun to clean.</p><p>In my opinion, the M240 meets all the requirements that you would expect of a high performance, heavy weapon.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa0657a69331a0011bc6cec?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Army paratroopers M240B Humvee\" height=\"1668\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US Army Paratroopers train on a M240B machine gun, mounted on a M1167 HMMWV, at Grafenwoehr Training Area in Germany, August 24, 2017.\n<p class=\"copyright\">US Army/VIS Gerhard Seuffert</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>First, it's extremely reliable: In my experience with it, jams are not common and when they do occur, they are usually easy to clear — an important aspect of survivability. The M240 is also easy to jam feed, which allows you to keep your barrel on target and get back in the fight quicker. The barrels are light and easy to change out. Finally, their internals are not very complicated, making cleaning and maintenance a breeze.</p><p>I mostly shot the M240 from a mount, but we did do some training carrying them around. The point is, if your vehicle or boat is put out of service, you can take the M240 off the mount and keep going if need be. With an effective range of 1,100 meters, an M240 can reach way out.</p><p>After spending extensive time with each of these weapons systems, I would choose the M240 every day of the week and twice on Sunday. Its reliability, accuracy, and easy operational use are unparalleled.</p><p><em>Jonathan is a former Navy SWCC and Special Operations Combat Medic. He has extensive experience in maritime special operations and combat medicine. He possesses a B.S. in Organizational Leadership, a B.S. in Marine Engineering Technology, and is working towards a Master's in Engineering Technical Management.</em></p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/why-the-m240-is-the-us-militarys-best-machine-gun-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/eKcTszwjwrw\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 02 Nov 2020 20:15:03 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5fa066f891178a0019b3dc2a?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5c3295a358900812d5daae896177a771","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn60@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-35-528_ddd07e86ca728485.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":160658,"destBytes":160658,"author":"insider@insider.com (Jonathan Weiss)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5fa061e56f5b310011724e74?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn37@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-50-923_73c4f4b509cd291a.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa0657569331a0011bc6ceb?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn93@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-36-757_afde01ed2f7c8c57.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa065786f5b310011724e80?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn6@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-50-830_de09895e51ee7455.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa0657a69331a0011bc6cec?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn40@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-57-360_a5c155d636c3fae7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-293_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn40@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-54-129_7ce010894d624eb8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn27@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-58-850_b7cb44b68b66e01e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eKcTszwjwrw:sbFpNSQKzPQ:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn2@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-46-207_1f21e70609f7cd3d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/eKcTszwjwrw":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-54-367_9f5201905670d4ff.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604381490575},{"createdTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"New York Democrat Mondaire Jones wants to bring a progressive edge to Congress","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/mondaire-jones-new-york-17th-district-house-congressional-election-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9e48b469331a0011bc6954?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mondaire-Jones-2\" height=\"3712\" width=\"5568\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Mondaire Jones is the Democratic nominee for New York&#39;s 17th Congressional district.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Michael Noble Jr. for The Washington Post via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Mondaire Jones is the Democratic nominee for New York's 17th Congressional district, located in the northern suburbs of New York City.</li>\n<li>Jones is running on a progressive platform, strongly supporting the Green New Deal, Medicare for All, and student loan debt cancelation.</li>\n<li>Reforming the judiciary &#8212; specifically the Supreme Court &#8212; is a pressing issue for Jones, who worked at the Department of Justice in the administration of former president Barack Obama.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>When Mondaire Jones jumped in the race for New York's 17th Congressional district in July 2019, he was setting up a primary challenge to the longtime Democratic incumbent, US Representative Nita Lowey.</p><p>Jones, a lawyer who supports the Green New Deal, Medicare for All, a $15 minimum wage, and the cancelation of student loan debt, felt that the district needed a bolder and more progressive voice. However, in October 2019, Lowey announced that she would retire at the end of her term and Jones found himself running for an open seat.</p><p>The district, in the northern suburbs of New York City, encompasses much of Westchester County and all of Rockland County. It is a mix of middle-class towns and villages, along with some of the most affluent communities in the country.</p><p>Jones, 33, grew up in Spring Valley, a village in Rockland County, where he was raised by his mother in Section 8 housing. He attended the local public schools before heading off to Stanford University and then Harvard Law School.</p><p>In his professional career, Jones has worked at the Department of Justice under then-President Barack Obama, where he dealt with judicial nominations for the White House, and also served as a litigator at the Westchester County District Attorney's office.</p><p>Jones, who watched multiple Obama judicial nominees endure lengthy Republican-initiated hearing delays while at the DOJ, has also been a longtime advocate of expanding the Supreme Court.</p><p>\"This is not a question of whether we want to do it or not,\" he said. \"We have to restore balance and preserve our democracy.\"</p><p>In the June primary, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/new-yorks-17th-district-democratic-primary-live-results-updates-2020-6\">Jones easily defeated</a> seven other candidates, becoming the favorite to win the Democratic-leaning seat on November 3.</p><p>If elected, Jones would be one of the first openly gay Black men to be elected to Congress. (Ritchie Torres, <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/04/nyregion/maloney-torres-ny-congressional-races.html\">from the nearby 15th Congressional district of New York</a>, identifies as Afro-Latino and is expected to win on Election Day.)</p><p>Jones recently spoke with Business Insider about his campaign. Below are edited excerpts from that interview.</p><p><strong>Q. If elected to the House, how do you view your role influencing possible court reform measures that would largely be under the Senate's purview?</strong></p><p><strong>A.</strong> Article III of the US Constitution vests the authority to create the federal courts and alter the size of the Supreme Court. There could be court expansion included in H.R. 1 [the sweeping voting rights and ethics legislation that House Democrats passed in March 2019, which was blocked by GOP Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell of Kentucky], which is what a democracy reform package should look like. We have to add judges at all levels of the federal judiciary in order to insure that litigants get the justice that they deserve.</p><p><strong>How would you tackle the student loan debt crisis?</strong></p><p>For the vast majority of people, a college education is required, while wages have stagnated. The cost of college and amount of debt that people carry after graduation has significantly increased.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9e45f069331a0011bc6953?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Mondaire-Jones-3\" height=\"3605\" width=\"5407\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jones speaks at a Black Lives Matter rally in Irvington, New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Kevin Hagen</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>My proposal is to make sure that all public colleges and universities are tuition-free, while forgiving the college debt that current exists. It will liberate an entire generation to fully participate in the economy.</p><p><strong>What would you say to those who feel that tuition-free college can't be accomplished?</strong></p><p>The data shoes that debt forgiveness is a boon to the economy. We're already paying for not making college affordable and accessible to all. The student debt crisis at the undergraduate level is $1.7 trillion nationally, yet we passed a COVID-19 relief bill earlier this year that involved spending more than that.</p><p><strong>There hasn't been a stimulus measure signed into law since this April, with little relief in sight to unemployed Americans and small businesses. What would your ideal stimulus package look like?</strong></p><p>It has to be <a href=\"https://financialservices.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=406440\">some iteration of what [Congresswoman] Maxine Waters proposed</a>. Until the coronavirus crisis is over, there would be monthly checks of $2,000 for every adult and $1,000 for each child, as opposed to a one-time check. The previous bill [CARES Act] didn't even take into account college students. There would be rental assistance for our small businesses, many of which are really struggling right now. [Washington State Congresswoman] Pramila Jayapal's Paycheck Guarantee Act would ensure that people remain employed with their salary and benefits. The package has to include trillions in aid for state and local municipalities that are really struggling to provide essential government services.</p><p><strong>What are some environmental priorities that you'd like to see in the US?</strong></p><p>Investing in green infrastructure would create 20 million new jobs. Incinerators are often built in majority-minority communities, resulting in higher asthma rates for residents. We have to tackle environmental injustice and racism, which means prioritizing investments in underserved communities impacted by adverse decisions.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/mondaire-jones-new-york-17th-district-house-congressional-election-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/B4AaAODBYHI\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 02 Nov 2020 20:42:52 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/5f9e96bd69331a0011bc6967?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"db7a36a83b72a49163a72c3af4a7b3a2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn47@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-35-503_89227f644f87c21e.webp","destWidth":4949,"destHeight":3712,"sourceBytes":381662,"destBytes":381662,"author":"insider@insider.com (John L. Dorman)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5f9e48b469331a0011bc6954?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn97@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-37-754_56d076f44c44d6cd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9e45f069331a0011bc6953?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn74@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-55-572_38836ac1976371e7.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-293_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn54@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-37-139_672d9adcf34f1c4a.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn19@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-41-572_556f9754d90662f0.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=B4AaAODBYHI:QRxnhxcrvrA:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn46@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-36-314_0b9b9d467008df86.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/B4AaAODBYHI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn64@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-44-241_1a496f61dde4843e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604381490555},{"createdTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"Incumbent Democrat TJ Cox and David Valadao square up for a rematch in California's 21st Congressional District","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/california-21st-house-district-election-tj-cox-david-valadao-2020","description":"<bi-shortcode id=\"hero-media\" class=\"mceNonEditable\" data-type=\"embed\" data-aspect-ratio=\"56.25%\" data-full-width=\"false\" data-embed-type=\"ddhq\" data-script-src=\"https://embeds.ddhq.io/single/v3/ddhq.load.js?\">&#160;</bi-shortcode><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Rep. TJ Cox is running in a rematch against Republican David Valadao, who he previously defeated in 2018's midterm elections.&#160;</li>\n<li>See the live coverage and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-house-elections-results\">full results from all US House elections.</a></li>\n<li>California's 21st Congressional District, located in California's San Joaquin Valley, consists of Kings County and pieces of Kern, Tulare, and Fresno counties.</li>\n<li>The Fresno Bee's editorial board recently endorsed Valadao for the seat after Cox was embroiled in scandals over his business dealings and unpaid taxes. Each candidate has close to $2 million in cash on hand.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><strong>Democratic Rep. TJ Cox</strong> and Republican <strong>David Valadao</strong> are set for a rematch in California's 21st Congressional District as Valadao looks to reclaim the House seat he once held for three terms. In 2018, Cox defeated Valadao by only 862 votes, a margin of 0.8 percentage points, in a tightly contested race.</p><h2>The candidates</h2><p>Rep. TJ Cox is a California native <a href=\"https://tjcoxforcongress.com/about-tj\">campaigning for reelection on a platform</a> of immigration policy reform, supporting schools, and healthcare for all, and has consistently hammered Valadao on his vote to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Previously an engineer working on water conveyance systems and dams, Cox has introduced <a href=\"https://cox.house.gov/media/press-releases/representative-tj-cox-secures-wins-central-valley-water-house-infrastructure\">multiple bills</a> and passed one item of legislation to increase the quality of central California's drinking water and river restoration infrastructure.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f283b665af6cc11ed0805a6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"TJ cox at rally\" height=\"1758\" width=\"3516\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Democratic Rep. TJ Cox (CA-21).\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mario Tama/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Valadao, a former member of the California State Assembly and farmer, has been in politics for most of his life. The son of Portuguese immigrants, Valadao noted that he <a href=\"https://www.fresnobee.com/news/politics-government/politics-columns-blogs/political-notebook/article86701207.html\">could not support</a> then-candidate Donald Trump's campaign for the presidency in 2016. But after President Trump was elected, Valadao voted in line with the president 97.9% of the time <a href=\"https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/congress-trump-score/david-g-valadao/\">according to FiveThirtyEight</a>, and is supporting Trump in 2020.&#160;</p><p>Cox has faced some scrutiny and controversy in his short tenure in Congress for <a href=\"https://www.visaliatimesdelta.com/story/news/2020/02/19/tj-cox-david-valadao-face-questions-business-dealings/4787198002/\">owing over $140,000 in unpaid federal taxes</a>, <a href=\"https://www.fresnobee.com/news/local/article234047417.html\">and owing tens of thousands of back wages to workers,</a> initially failing to disclose some of his financial holdings, and, <a href=\"https://www.fresnobee.com/news/politics-government/politics-columns-blogs/political-notebook/article219337805.html\">as the Fresno Bee reported</a>, listing two separate primary residences in Maryland and California for tax purposes, which Cox explained as an \"honest mistake\" and subsequently fixed. He eventually did pay back employee back wages.&#160;</p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.fresnobee.com/opinion/editorials/article240603301.html\">Bee has now endorsed Valadao over Cox in the race</a>, writing: \"While Cox has sponsored or cosponsored useful legislation in his first term, the financial revelations raise questions about Cox's credibility. Voters should retire Cox and bring back Valadao, who is once again seeking the seat.\"</p><h3><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/2020-house-elections-results\">See Insider's full coverage of the race for the House of Representatives</a></h3><h2>The district</h2><p>Located in the south-central region of California, the state's 21st Congressional District comprises Kings County and portions of Tulare, Kern, and Fresno counties. A little over 70% of the district is Hispanic and has a median household income of $37,228, according to the 2010 US Census.</p><p>The district backed President Barack Obama by 11 points in 2012 and voted for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton by a margin of over 15 points in 2016, <a href=\"https://www.dailykos.com/stories/2012/11/19/1163009/-Daily-Kos-Elections-presidential-results-by-congressional-district-for-the-2012-2008-elections\">according to the Daily Kos.</a></p><h2>The money race</h2><p>According to campaign finance filings, the incumbent, Cox, <a href=\"https://www.fec.gov/data/candidate/H8CA10167/\">has raised</a> $5.1 million, spent $4.6 million, and has around $535,000 in cash on hand. <a href=\"https://www.fec.gov/data/candidate/H2CA20094/\">His opponent, Valadao</a>, raised $3.7 million in the same period of time, spent $2.9 million, and has around $931,600 on hand.&#160;</p><h2>What some of the experts say</h2><p>The race between Cox and Valadao is rated as a \"toss-up\" by <a href=\"https://cookpolitical.com/ratings/house-race-ratings\">The Cook Political Report</a> and <a href=\"https://insideelections.com/ratings/house\">Inside Elections</a> and \"leans Democratic\" by <a href=\"http://centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/2020-house/\">Sabato's Crystal Ball at the University of Virginia Center for Politics</a><a href=\"https://insideelections.com/ratings/house\">.</a></p><bi-shortcode id=\"expanded-coverage\" class=\"mceNonEditable\" data-source=\"insider-voter-guide\" data-show-header=\"false\">Expanded Coverage Module: insider-voter-guide</bi-shortcode><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/california-21st-house-district-election-tj-cox-david-valadao-2020'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=mYs7CI3PaAk:JOI_OQk7bSs:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img
