boring","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/dana-perino-profile-photos-fox-news-host-bush-press-secretary-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29c29bb6d52d4dc946bda5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino at Fox News Channel Studios on July 31, 2018 in New York.\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino at Fox News Channel Studios on July 31, 2018 in New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">John Lamparski/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Dana Perino, 48, is the host of Fox News' \"The Daily Briefing,\" a commentator on the \"The Five,\" and co-host of the Fox podcast \"I'll Tell You What.\"</li>\n<li>At age six, Perino told her family that she would one day work in the White House. She studied journalism at graduate school, but after refusing to interview the mother of a murdered 2-year-old child, she decided the profession wasn't for her.</li>\n<li>Perino transitioned into communications, in both the public and private sphere, before she worked her way up to becoming former President George W. Bush's press secretary.</li>\n<li>After Bush left office, she began contributing to Fox News, first defending Bush's legacy, then providing her own opinions.</li>\n<li>During the pandemic, she's been working remotely from her beach house in Bay Head, New Jersey, where she hosts her shows from a spare bedroom.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Fox News host Dana Perino has gone from defending a president's opinions to spouting her own.</p><p>Perino, a life-long conservative, planned on becoming a journalist, but ended up in communications. She worked her way up to become former President George W. Bush's White House press secretary, delivering&#160;<a href=\"https://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/01/16/the-final-press-conference/\">145 press briefings</a>.</p><p>She's been on Fox News for nearly a decade, first defending Bush's legacy then discussing her own opinions. She's written two best-selling books, and she calls Bush a second father.</p><p>But when Insider spoke (via Zoom) with Perino in August to discuss her life to date, she said: \"I worry sometimes, I think the audience might think I'm too boring.\"</p><p>\"I've been called the voice of reason. I don't know if that's always true, but I am a voice of calm,\" she said.</p><p>Here's a look at her life and career, in photos, based on interviews with Perino and sourcing from the <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/dana-m-perino/gIQARPJYAP_print.html\">Washington Post</a>, <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20120609135344/http:/archive.newsmax.com/archives/articles/2007/4/29/210953.shtml\">News Max</a>, <a href=\"https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2019/04/15/dana-perino-fox-news-the-five/3366402002/\">Tennessean</a>,&#160;<a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/media/dana-perino-opens-up-about-life-as-white-house-press-secretary-bush\">Fox News</a>, <a href=\"http://danaperino.com/portfolio/testi/\">Diapering.com</a>, <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20130227054228/https:/www.uiaa.org/uis/news/uisalumni/stxt0708.html\">University of Illinois Alumni Association</a>, her <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Good-News-Lessons-Advice-Bright/dp/B01LTHXJNM\">memoir</a>, <a href=\"https://www.austinchronicle.com/news/2007-09-21/540646/\">Austin Chronicle</a>, <a href=\"https://web.archive.org/web/20080918014941/http:/www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/article3022248.ece\">The Sunday Times</a>, <a href=\"https://www.denverpost.com/2007/08/31/parkers-dana-perino-steps-into-white-house-spotlight/\">Denver Post</a>, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/story/2015/04/dana-perinos-bush-white-house-117162\">Politico</a>, <a href=\"https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-2007-mar-31-na-perino31-story.html\">Los Angeles Times</a>, <a href=\"https://time.com/3828643/dana-perino-memoir/\">Time</a>, <a href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/04/23/401519398/a-black-eye-flipping-the-bird-and-other-tales-from-a-white-house-press-secretary\">NPR</a>, <a href=\"https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/12/dana-perinos-ready-for-a-glass-of-red-wine\">Vanity Fair</a>, <a href=\"https://www.mediaite.com/tv/dana-perinos-rising-stature-in-fox-news-post-shep-landscape-a-mediaite-qa/\">Mediaite</a>, <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/30/dana-perino-trump-candidacy-has-set-gop-women-adrift/92882442/\">USA Today</a>, <a href=\"https://apnews.com/aa36bdad9f2a401d986f78b627074b38\">AP</a>, <a href=\"https://deadline.com/2017/04/bill-oreilly-fired-the-factor-name-removed-1202072743/\">Deadline</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.salon.com/2020/04/07/top-biologist-to-fox-news-host-dana-perino-unproven-drug-treatment-hyped-by-trump-is-a-quack-cure/\">Salon</a>.</p>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tDana Perino was born on May 9, 1972 in Evanston, Wyoming. Her family moved to Parker, outside of Denver, Colorado, when she was 2 years old.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1a69331a0011bc693d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino was born on May 9, 1972 in Evanston, Wyoming. Her family moved to Parker, outside of Denver, Colorado, when she was 2 years old.\" height=\"1335\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Every Friday night, her parents would go two-step dancing, and the first songs she remembered hearing were Kenny Rogers' \"The Gambler\" and \"Islands in the Stream.\"</p>\n\tPolitics and the media were early influences. When she was six years old, after her family visited the White House, she climbed onto a milk crate and declared she would one day work there.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe146f5b310011724af3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Politics and the media were early influences. When she was six years old, after her family visited the White House, she climbed onto a milk crate and declared she would one day work there.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1965\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPerino spent her summers on her grandfather’s ranch in Newcastle, Wyoming. She told Fox News the lifestyle helped her keep positive and calm.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1d69331a0011bc6941?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Perino spent her summers on her grandfather’s ranch in Newcastle, Wyoming. She told Fox News the lifestyle helped her keep positive and calm.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1968\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"Ranchers, by their nature, have to be optimistic,\" she said. \"They have to believe that the cattle will survive the winter and that the crops are going to grow &#8212; so I think I have a sunny disposition naturally.\"</p>\n\tDana and her sister Angie were expected to debate current events at the dinner table. Every afternoon, from third grade on, Perino read the Rocky Mountain News and the Denver Post before Leo, her father, got home from work.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe0b69331a0011bc693b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana and her sister Angie were expected to debate current events at the dinner table. Every afternoon, from third grade on, Perino read the Rocky Mountain News and the Denver Post before Leo, her father, got home from work.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1972\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She read them to prepare for a discussion about two articles from the day. Leo told News Max that he wanted his children to understand there were always two sides to each story.</p>\n\tIt was Leo’s tradition that got her interested in journalism. She also joined the high school debate team when she was 13, and continued all the way to college. She said debating had a huge impact on her life.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1a6f5b310011724af5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"It was Leo’s tradition that got her interested in journalism. She also joined the high school debate team when she was 13, and continued all the way to college. She said debating had a huge impact on her life.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1987\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIn 1994, she enrolled in Colorado State University Pueblo. She majored in communications and politics, and got a full scholarship through her debating.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1b69331a0011bc693f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"In 1994, she enrolled in Colorado State University Pueblo. She majored in communications and politics, and got a full scholarship through her debating.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1707\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tShe worked as country music DJ from 2 a.m. to 6 a.m. every weekend to bolster her resume. She was on air while the top song was Bill Ray Cyrus’s “Achy Breaky Heart,” which she had to play once every hour when it was first released.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1c6f5b310011724af6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"She worked as country music DJ from 2 a.m. to 6 a.m. every weekend to bolster her resume. She was on air while the top song was Bill Ray Cyrus’s “Achy Breaky Heart,” which she had to play once every hour when it was first released.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1383\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Country-pop singer Billy Ray Cyrus performs in Nashville on June 9, 1992. Cyrus&#39;s song &#34;Achy Breaky Heart&#34; has topped the charts.\n<p class=\"copyright\">AP Photo/Mark Humphrey</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tDespite a conservative upbringing, she considered voting for former President Bill Clinton after he visited her campus for a rally. She couldn't remember what he said but she recalled the seductive energy of his campaign.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1c69331a0011bc6940?format=jpeg\" alt=\"PerinoPhoto K (1)\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1961\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>In her memoir, she wrote: \"There was no substantive reason for supporting Clinton in my mind &#8212; it was more about wanting to feel reinvigorated, something new. Which, I learned later, can be very seductive. And dangerous.\"</p>\n\tAfter graduating, she got a master’s degree in public affairs reporting from the University of Illinois Springfield. She told Insider she was “absolutely dead set” on becoming a journalist, and took out a student loan to get the degree.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe0f69331a0011bc693c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"After graduating, she got a master’s degree in public affairs reporting from the University of Illinois Springfield. She told Insider she was “absolutely dead set” on becoming a journalist, and took out a student loan to get the degree.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1993\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"It was a very small program. They only accepted 18 people per year because there were 18 potential internships at the state capital with media companies,\" she said.</p><p>She got a television reporting internship at the local CBS affiliate in Champagne, Illinois.</p><p>\"I really liked the politics,\" she said. \"But then I would get sent out to cover stories that didn't have anything to do with politics. I remember I covered a tornado and the aftermath of damage. And I kind of fell apart.\"</p>\n\tHer plan to become a reporter was faltering, and it ended when she refused to interview a woman about her murdered 2 year old son.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1a6f5b310011724af4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Her plan to become a reporter was faltering, and it ended when she refused to interview a woman about her murdered 2 year old son.\" height=\"1327\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino attends the Radio and Television Correspondents&#39; Association dinner at the Washington Hilton Hotel March 28, 2007 in Washington.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jonathan Ernst/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"I saw her, and I walked around her three times. I couldn't approach her. At the time I didn't know how. I just kind of choked,\" she told Insider.</p><p>She called her dad, who told her it was okay.</p><p>Leo said: \"After graduation, I'll pick you up. We'll drive back and listen. You'll see. You'll figure it out.\"</p><p>She returned to her family home to figure out her next step. But she couldn't twiddle her thumbs.</p><p>\"I needed to get a job and make money,\" she told Insider.</p><p>\"There used to be a thing called the 1-800 media line. You would call up and you would hear about the jobs that were available around the country. And the pay was very, very low. And I had ambition and I still do. But really, at the time, I was looking at this going, how do you work your way up?\"</p><p>\"I didn't understand. I didn't want to be stuck in these smaller media markets. I was going to start there, but I wanted to do other stuff.\"</p><p>While she hunted for jobs, she worked as a waitress at a local restaurant making good money. When a communications job came up in Denver, she decided to apply, based on the fact she knew a bit about politics, and, she said, \"of course I'd watched The West Wing.\"</p>\n\tIn August 1995, Perino got a job as a staff assistant to former Rep. Scott McInnis after contacting him for a reference. She had interviewed him during college, and his staff remembered and asked her to come work for him.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28c58324306a66835be62e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Rep. Scott McInnis, R-Colo., Rep. Daniel Schaefer, R-Colo on the left during a 1995 press conference.\" height=\"919\" width=\"1225\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rep. Scott McInnis, R-Colo., Rep. Daniel Schaefer, R-Colo on the left during a 1995 press conference.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Laura Patterson/CQ Roll Call / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Three months later, she moved on, and started working as former Rep. Dan Schaefer's press secretary.</p>\n\tPerino networked, making sure to keep in contact with people she met before social media existed, using postcards.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29b2e8b6d52d3a0b11ec26?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino in 2007.\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino in 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brooks Kraft LLC / Corbis / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She said the idea for the postcards came from writing letters to her grandparents every weekend.</p><p>\"I used to love postcards,\" she told Insider. \"I think I was an early networker, natural networker. I knew one way to succeed was to build your network. It doesn't require a lot of effort. It's not a huge commitment. But it's a reminder.\"</p>\n\tIn the summer of 1997, Perino heard at a dinner party that George W. Bush was running for re-election as Texas governor. She thought he would use his position to launch a bid for president.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa03c2069331a0011bc6bb3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"george w bush as texas governor\" height=\"1333\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>George W. Bush when he was governor of Texas in February 1998.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/the-texas-governor-george-bush-news-photo/543871170\" target=\"_blank\">F. Carter Smith/Sygma via Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She told her friends to call her when he ran, because she wanted to help Bush run for president.</p>\n\tIn was around then, in 1997, when she was 25 and living in Washington, that she began to experience a \"quarter-life crisis,\" she wrote in her memoir. Dating was a struggle.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b05f62fa8153517a54b7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"White House staff members (L-R) Tony Snow, Dana Perino, Dan Bartlett, Karl Rove and Nicole Wallace listen to United States President George W. Bush as he holds a press conference in the Rose Garden at the White House June 14, 2006 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1412\" width=\"1883\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino, second from left, in Washington, DC, nearly a decade later in 2006.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"Most of the guys didn't look like they'd ever worked outside a day in their lives &#8212; soft hands, limp handshakes, pale skin, and pudgy middles. The good-looking ones were either already hitched or married to their political ambition with little senses of humor. It was slim pickings for a single woman,\" she wrote.</p>\n\tOn August 17, 1997, she met her husband Peter McMahon. They were the last two people to board a flight leaving Denver. McMahon was reading John Le Carre's \"The Tailor of Panama,\" which got them talking.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28c407b6d52d62983729b3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Peter McMahon and Dana Perino attend the George H.W. Bush Points of Light Awards Gala at the Intrepid Sea, Air &#38; Space Museum on Thursday, Sept. 26, 2019, in New York.\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Peter McMahon and Dana Perino attend the George H.W. Bush Points of Light Awards Gala at the Intrepid Sea, Air &#38; Space Museum on Thursday, Sept. 26, 2019, in New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Charles Sykes / Invision / AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIn 2007, she told The Times: \"It gives me chills to think how close I was to not meeting him. I couldn't get him out of my head. I couldn't eat, sleep, or concentrate on work.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1e69331a0011bc6942?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Perino family\" height=\"1811\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>At one point during our Zoom interview, Perino paused to ask him if he could do the dishes at some other time.</p><p>McMahon, who is 18 years older than Perino, has played a key supporting role in her life, handling the majority of the housework, and driving her to work when he was in town, while she worked in the White House.&#160;</p>\n\tAfter getting married, they spent a year in England. Perino couldn't work because she didn't have the right visa. She volunteered and read historical fiction. On the weekends she made McMahon take them to the places in her books.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe086f5b310011724af0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"After a year in England, they moved to San Diego, ticking off a dream of Perino’s to live in California. For three years, she worked in corporate PR, thinking the skills would transfer easily, but the focus on venture capital wasn’t for her.\" height=\"1751\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She said taking a year off work was never part of her career plan.</p><p>\"I remember thinking, what are people going to think about me not working? What are people going to think about me stopping my career at this point? I was on a pretty strict trajectory. But I was so in love. And I loved the idea of adventure.\"</p><p>While they were in England, Perino was alone at home all day.</p><p>\"I was on the internet all the time. I didn't know that you had to pay by the minute. I was there during Lewinsky scandal, for the trial, and the Clinton impeachment. I was online all day, constantly refreshing,\" she said.</p><p>McMahon told later her internet usage cost them about 600 pounds (almost $800).</p>\n\tThe couple bought a Hungarian Vizsla puppy from Scotland that they named Henry after the British King Henry VIII.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe126f5b310011724af2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"During their time in England, they also bought a Hungarian Vizsla puppy from Scotland that they named Henry after the British King Henry VIII.\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1645\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She later trained Henry to fetch flip flops by asking the dog what he thought of former Secretary of State John Kerry.</p><p>When Henry heard the words \"John Kerry\" he would go find them, alluding, she said, to Bush trying to define Kerry as a \"flip flopper.\"</p>\n\tAfter a year in England, they moved to San Diego, ticking off a dream of Perino's to live in California. For three years, she worked in corporate PR, thinking the skills would transfer easily, but the focus on venture capital wasn't for her.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29afec24306a38ea48c0c5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"White House Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino steps off Air Force One upon return to Andrews Air Force Base 12 August 2007 in Maryland.\" height=\"1462\" width=\"1949\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino steps off Air Force One upon return to Andrews Air Force Base 12 August 2007 in Maryland.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mandel Ngan / AFP / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"It became a little unsatisfying,\" she said. \"It wasn't like they were trying to solve issues. They were just trying to get more attention so they could get venture capital money.\"</p><p>In 2017, she told Business Insider that she's never experienced sexual harassment, but at that job she was furious to discover a male colleague was paid $5,000 more than her a year.</p><p>She confronted her boss, who told her the other man had a family to feed, but she dismissed that, and the following day she got a raise.</p>\n\tPerino was still in San Diego when the Bush campaign call finally came through. A friend asked her to volunteer as a campaign spokeswoman in California, but she couldn't afford to — McMahon had just started a new business and they were relying on her job for benefits.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f3af9bea3eafa001de069bd?format=jpeg\" alt=\"George W. Bush campaign plane\" height=\"1515\" width=\"2048\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She said no, thinking she had just lost her chance to work for Bush. \"I hung up the phone and I cried,\" she said.</p>\n\tHer next career move came in 2001, via another phone call. Perino checked up on a friend of hers working in the Department of Justice after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. A few days later her friend asked her to move to DC to work as a spokeswoman for the department, focusing on environmental issues.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29b26824306a3b6d336cf6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino in 2007.\" height=\"2626\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino in 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Saul Loeb / AFP / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She made the move. Her clearance came through in December.</p>\n\tIn 2002, she was brought into the White House to work on the Bush administration's environmental policy.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29af4324306a38695c1686?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Reporter Ann Compton (R) talks with White House spokeswoman Dana Perino (2nd-R) in a stairwell as White House staff stand nearby after a briefing that focused on White House Press Secretary Tony Snow at the White House March 27, 2007 in Washington DC.\" height=\"1483\" width=\"1977\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Reporter Ann Compton (R) talks with White House spokeswoman Dana Perino (2nd-R) in a stairwell as White House staff stand nearby after a briefing that focused on White House Press Secretary Tony Snow at the White House March 27, 2007 in Washington DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mark Wilson / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tOn Inauguration Day in 2005, Perino became the deputy press secretary for the White House. Former White House press secretary Scott McClellan, who offered her the job, told the Denver Post it was \"one of the best decisions\" he had made.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29b18462fa813ed156c455?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino listens to a briefing with other members of the administration in the White House briefing room August 31, 2007 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1307\" width=\"1742\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino listens to a briefing with other members of the administration in the White House briefing room August 31, 2007 in Washington, DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brendan Smialowski/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>He said she could quickly understand complex policies, and explain them in an accessible way.</p><p>She told the Post she was happy she hadn't got Tony Snow's job as the White House's main press secretary.</p><p>\"Tony is one of the best on-camera briefers I have ever seen,\" she said. \"Anyone who comes next is going to pale in comparison. I don't want to be that person.\"</p><p>But she was that person.</p>\n\tIn September 2007, she became the official press secretary after Snow had to step down, because he had terminal cancer.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b2f324306a5232760c36?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino, the new Press Secretary President for George W. Bush, takes questions from the White House press corps during her first day September 17, 2007 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino, the new Press Secretary President for George W. Bush, takes questions from the White House press corps during her first day on September 17, 2007 in Washington, DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She was the second woman to serve as press secretary, and the first Republican woman.</p><p>But she nearly quit before she got the job.</p><p>Perino was planning on resigning when then-director of communications Ed Gillespie asked to have a word with her.</p><p>In the meeting, Gillespie asked if he could speak first. He told her they'd like her to be the new press secretary. Perino did not mention her plan to quit. Instead she accepted her promotion.</p>\n\tPerino is 5-foot-1, so during her time as press secretary, the lectern and the White House emblem were lowered so that she and the image were in the same frame.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b27b24306a51b46bc3a2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"US Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino speaks at a briefing at the White House 27 March 2007.\" height=\"1378\" width=\"1837\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>US Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino speaks at a briefing at the White House 27 March 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Nicholas Kamm / AFP / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tShe was a big fan of Bush's. As James Gerstenzang put it for the Los Angeles Times: \"Clearly, she cares about her subject. And that subject is all things Bush.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29a9aa62fa8138277cef42?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Bush hugs Perino in 2007.\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Bush hugs Perino in 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ron Edmonds / AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She told Business Insider in 2017 that covering policies she did not agree with never bothered her. It was not about her, she said. It was her job to simply explain how the decision had been made.</p>\n\tShe mostly kept her cool under pressure. She told NPR that she imagined Bush watching and only said things that he'd be proud of. When a reporter really got under her nerves, she said she \"would flip him the bird\" hidden behind the podium.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29cea3b6d52d5d301c02c4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"White House Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino holds up her finger in 2007.\" height=\"1492\" width=\"1989\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House Deputy Press Secretary Dana Perino holds up her finger in 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Gerald Herbert / AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tPerino might not have been as combative as Snow, but she didn't take things lying down. When ABC swapped its reporter Jessica Yellin for then up-and-coming reporter Jake Tapper, and robbed Yellin of a question at a press briefing, Perino was annoyed.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa0675e91178a0019b3dc2d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jake tapper\" height=\"1202\" width=\"1603\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/new-white-house-correspondent-jake-tapper-taping-a-stand-up-news-photo/97163454?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">Bill O&#39;Leary/The Washington Post/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She told Bush, and he asked whether they had to let Tapper have a question. She said they didn't and they decided to ignore his question.</p><p>Tapper was reportedly \"furious,\" but later told the Washington Post it was a shame he didn't get asked his question, because it was going to be about pay raises for White House communications staff.</p>\n\tPandemics were briefly a subject of concern during Perino's time in the White House. She told Insider that after Bush read up on the Spanish Flu, he was worried about whether the US was ready for another pandemic, and ordered the cabinet to carry out a test drill.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28be58b6d52d5c3909c63b?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Deputy White House Press Secretary Dana Perino briefs the press in Crawford, Texas, August 15, 2007.\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Deputy White House Press Secretary Dana Perino briefs the press in Crawford, Texas, August 15, 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Larry Downing / Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"It was a real stress test for the federal government,\" she said. \"I don't think it was an airborne illness. So we didn't have a debate about masks. But we did talk about, how do you get a vaccine ready? How do you communicate clearly to people so that they can protect themselves? Do we have the Coast Guard preventing people from coming in?\"</p><p>She told Insider she didn't like to compare how Bush would have handled the coronavirus against President Donald Trump, because every equation and fact pattern was different.</p><p>But the main difference she pointed to was international cooperation.</p><p>\"Remember we had a great, great coalition for the war on terror,\" she said. \"You could pretty easily then get everybody together. I think that might be a little different now.\"</p>\n\tIn December 2008, Perino got a black eye on the job in Iraq. A microphone swung into her face after a Secret Service agent knocked it trying to protect Bush from an Iraqi journalist who had thrown a shoe at the president.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e41c0ce3b62b73cb139e928?format=jpeg\" alt=\"An Iraqi man throws a shoe at President George W. Bush during a new conference with Iraq Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2008, in Baghdad.\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>An Iraqi man throws a shoe at President George W. Bush during a new conference with Iraq Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki on Sunday, Dec. 14, 2008, in Baghdad.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Evan Vucci / AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tBush saw her crying, and thought it was because of the shoe. She corrected him quickly, according to NPR. She said: \"Well, sir, I adore you, but I grew up in Wyoming and I'm a little tougher than that.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b0fcb6d52d4ebc2fc363?format=jpeg\" alt=\"White House Press Secretary Dana Perino speaks during the daily briefing at the White House in Washington, DC, December 16, 2008. Perino was slightly bruised in the shoe-throwing melee during President Bush&#39;s news conference at the Prime Minister&#39;s Palace in Baghdad.\" height=\"1391\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino was slightly bruised in the shoe-throwing melee during President Bush&#39;s news conference at the Prime Minister&#39;s Palace in Baghdad.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jim Watson / AFP / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Sources: <a href=\"https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/3797092/White-House-Press-Secretary-Dana-Perino-gets-black-eye-as-shoe-venir-in-Baghdad.html\">Telegraph</a>, <a href=\"https://time.com/3828643/dana-perino-memoir/\">Time</a></em></p>\n\tThe last seven months of Bush's tenure were the hardest, she wrote in her memoir.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29c712b6d52d546058e453?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino in 2008.\" height=\"1435\" width=\"1913\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino in 2008.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Bill O&#39;Leary/The The Washington Post / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>&#8220;I couldn&#8217;t sleep without a pill, my stomach wanted only bland foods, and I often forgot to eat until my assistant made me order something. &#8230; My back was so uncomfortable under my right shoulder blade that I practically stalked the osteopath on the President&#8217;s medical team,&#8221; she wrote.</p>\n\tPerino told Insider that travel was one of the biggest things that has stayed with her from her time in the White House, especially a visit to Africa in 2008.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b47924306a53d91d8f53?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Newly promoted White House Press Secretary Dana Perino poses with U.S. Marines during a visit to Al-Asad airbase with U.S. President George W. Bush in Anbar Province September 3, 2007.\" height=\"1381\" width=\"1841\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Newly promoted White House Press Secretary Dana Perino poses with U.S. Marines during a visit to Al-Asad airbase with U.S. President George W. Bush in Anbar Province September 3, 2007.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jason Reed / Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>For many years she answered questions about Bush's work in Africa, she said. \"But I hadn't really experienced it for myself. I was just memorizing points.\"</p><p>\"I remember every single moment of that trip, everything that we did every day. They have a lot of problems, but there is a lot of joy.\"</p>\n\tAfter leaving the White House, Perino spent a brief period vacationing and volunteering in South Africa, before she returned to the public eye, taking a contributor role at Fox News in April 2009.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b3b224306a530d66c1b4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"White House Spokesperson Dana Perino gestures toward the door during a the last daily press briefing of the Bush Administration at the White House January 16, 2008 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House Spokesperson Dana Perino gestures toward the door during the last daily press briefing of the Bush Administration at the White House January 16, 2008 in Washington, DC.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brendan Smialowski/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tShe told Business Insider she wanted to defend Bush's record, because the first two years after a president leaves involve constant comparisons. She talked to CNN about a role, as well, but said it was never a serious discussion.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29aab0b6d52d32b0370f52?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Sean Hannity, Dana Perino and Bob Beckel during the FOX News &#34;Hannity with Sean Hannity&#34; 15th anniversary show at Olympic Centennial Park on October 6, 2011 in Atlanta, Georgia. (\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sean Hannity, Dana Perino and Bob Beckel during the FOX News &#34;Hannity with Sean Hannity&#34; 15th anniversary show at Olympic Centennial Park on October 6, 2011 in Atlanta, Georgia.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chris McKay / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><em>Source: <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/story/2009/08/ex-bush-flacks-find-their-footing-026168\">Politico</a> </em></p>\n\tTransitioning from spokeswoman to opinion-maker did not come easily, at least not right away.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa0740a91178a0019b3dc86?format=jpeg\" alt=\"dana perino\" height=\"2000\" width=\"1610\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino host of &#34;The Five&#34; interviews Jenna Bush Hager and Barbara Bush during &#34;The Five&#34; at Fox News Studios on November 13, 2017 in New York City.\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/dana-perino-host-of-the-five-interviews-jenna-bush-hager-news-photo/873840228?adppopup=true\" target=\"_blank\">John Lamparski/Getty Images</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>At first, she said, \"I was mostly answering people's questions that had to do with the Bush administration versus the Obama administration. So still, in a lot of ways, it was like I was speaking for somebody.\"</p><p>But her job quickly required her own opinions. She said: \"And I had never done that. It was new to me and I was nervous about it, because even if I had said something during the Bush administration that was controversial, the criticism didn't back come to me.\"</p>\n\tIn July 2011, Fox News launched \"The Five,\" a talk show with five hosts, one of those being Perino, to fill the void of Glenn Beck leaving. It was only meant to run for five weeks. It's still going nine years later.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b6b362fa815ae5021ad5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Co-hosts Kimberly Guilfoyle, left, Julie Roginsky, Eric Bolling, and Dana Perino, right, interview U.S. Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla.,, during his appearance on &#34;The Five&#34; television program, on the Fox News Channel, in New York, Monday, March 30, 2015.\" height=\"1332\" width=\"1776\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sen. Marco Rubio during his appearance on &#34;The Five&#34; television program, on the Fox News Channel, in New York, Monday, March 30, 2015.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Richard Drew / AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tIn 2015, she released a memoir about her time as Bush's spokeswoman titled: \"And the Good News Is…Lessons and Advice from the Bright Side.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b14bb6d52d4f500866e5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"White House Press Secretary Dana Perino hands out boxes of presidential M&#38;M candy to journalists in the Brady Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC January 20, 2009.\" height=\"1438\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>White House Press Secretary Dana Perino hands out boxes of presidential M&#38;M candy to journalists in the Brady Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC January 20, 2009.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Mandel Ngan / AFP / Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She published her second book \"Let Me Tell You about Jasper: How My Best Friend Became America's Dog\" about her second Hungarian Vizsla called Jasper in 2016.</p>\n\tIn 2015, when Donald Trump announced he was running for president, Perino publicly ridiculed it, and questioned on which planet it would be a good idea.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29c29662fa8153de6bd336?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino at Fox News Channel Studios on July 31, 2018 in New York.\" height=\"1343\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino at Fox News Channel Studios on July 31, 2018 in New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">John Lamparski/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>As Trump campaigned in 2016, she told USA Today: \"I do feel adrift as a Republican woman, maybe a woman without a party. ... You sort of feel like, 'I don't know if I belong anymore.'\"</p><p>\"Now, there are plenty of Republican women that support Donald Trump fervently and passionately, without any hesitation. I just have hesitation and I don't know what I'm going to do. I don't know if I'm even going to vote, and I have a perfect voting record,\" she said.&#160;</p>\n\tIn April 2017, she was filling in for former anchor Bill O'Reilly when he was fired due to a series of sexual harassment allegations.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e41c1af4b661b3da44f0b38?format=jpeg\" alt=\"bill o reilly\" height=\"2003\" width=\"2671\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Ilya S. Savenok / Stringer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>She had the job of informing his audience he would not be coming back. She said it was the &#8220;end of an era&#8221; at Fox News and called him &#8220;the undisputed king of cable news.&#8221;</p>\n\tIn September 2017, Fox News announced a shake-up of its daytime lineup. Perino got her own show called \"The Daily Briefing with Dana Perino\" at 2 p.m. ET.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b34fb6d52d51e045b544?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino of FOX News poses for a photo at FOX Studios on October 17, 2017 in New York City.\" height=\"1373\" width=\"1831\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino of FOX News poses for a photo at FOX Studios on October 17, 2017 in New York City.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rob Kim/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Perino continued to ascend at Fox News. In 2018, she was chosen as the network's anchor to question Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg before Mark Zuckerberg testified before Congress.</p><p>The Associated Press called Perino &#8220;an honest broker of information&#8221; and a &#8220;Bush Republican in a Trump world.&#8221; It also said she wasn&#8217;t as brash as her former colleague Shepard Smith, but that she took &#8220;refuge in reporting.&#8221;</p>\n\tInsider asked whether she saw herself as a journalist after diverting from that path decades earlier. She said: \"I do.\"\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e28b6e762fa815b10686093?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Fox News contributor and Host of the Daily Briefing, Dana Perino, right, interviewing former Vice President Dan Quayle, left, at Fox Studios in Washington, Tuesday, Dec. 4, 2018.\" height=\"1267\" width=\"1689\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Fox News contributor and Host of the Daily Briefing, Dana Perino, right, interviewing former Vice President Dan Quayle, left, at Fox Studios in Washington, Tuesday, Dec. 4, 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pablo Martinez Monsivais / AP</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"I think I'm a much better journalist now after all that I've done. I look at both sides. I'm pretty cautious. What has been gratifying for me [is that] I do think that I've earned the trust of my audience, the people I reach out to.\"</p><p>She also said: \"I worry sometimes; I think the audience might think I'm too boring. But I think people listen when I speak. I've been called the voice of reason. I don't know if that's always true, but I am a voice of calm.\"</p>\n\tIn April, she invited renowned biologist Dr. William Haseltine onto Fox News. Haseltine dismissed hydroxychloroquine, the controversial malaria drug that had been touted elsewhere by other Fox News anchors like Laura Ingraham.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e29bd5424306a48ed1aae63?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana Perino speaks at The 2017 Concordia Annual Summit at Grand Hyatt New York on September 19, 2017 in New York City.\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1778\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Dana Perino speaks at The 2017 Concordia Annual Summit at Grand Hyatt New York on September 19, 2017 in New York City.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Riccardo Savi/Getty</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>Insider asked if she interviewed people, like Haseltine, who other Fox News hosts would not. She said: \"I love to interview experts. I like the experts. I trust them.\"</p>\n\tPerino told Insider the biggest concerns Republicans had going forward were the coronavirus, its effect on the economy, law and order, and racial conflicts.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1d6f5b310011724af7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The common thread of her life has been being at the right place at the right time, she said. And for the first time she’s not concerned about what she’s going to do next.\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>\"When I was press secretary, the No. 1 worry in America was terrorism,\" she said.</p><p>\"I think it's pretty remarkable that that it is not our biggest worry [anymore]. Obviously President Trump takes a lot of credit for ISIS.\"</p>\n\tAs staff work remotely during the pandemic, Perino is no longer working from the Fox News studio in New York. She's been hosting from her beach house in Bay Head, New Jersey, and has been a key part of Fox New's 2020 election coverage.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe096f5b310011724af1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"As staff work remotely during the pandemic, Perino is no longer working from the Fox News studio in New York. She’s been hosting from her beach house in Bay Head, New Jersey, and has been a key part of Fox New’s 2020 election coverage.\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t\n\tThe common thread of her life has been being at the right place at the right time, she said. And for the first time she's not concerned about what she's going to do next.\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1b69331a0011bc693e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Dana\" height=\"1429\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Dana Perino/Fox News</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>As for the future, she said she's most looking forward to the 2024 elections.&#160;</p><p>\"No matter what happens in 2020, both parties are going to be at a crossroads, and have shifting coalitions, and it is going to be fascinating to see who emerges from both parties as the nominee during an election,\" she said.</p><p>\"So I am here for all of that.\"</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a (James Pasley)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e29c29bb6d52d4dc946bda5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn10@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-55-057_4884ebc994261c11.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1a69331a0011bc693d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn21@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-36-918_6afa636d97103c66.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe146f5b310011724af3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn26@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-193_8413068ad9c2c982.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1d69331a0011bc6941?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn33@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-55-821_88cf74d52f661f46.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe0b69331a0011bc693b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn23@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-57-234_6b62050d7a8f2558.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1a6f5b310011724af5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn35@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-40-914_bc032041bcbd24d0.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1b69331a0011bc693f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn18@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-52-378_bc27aba3ad9eea75.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1c6f5b310011724af6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn85@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-34-335_9fd9ffac0786aa4e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1c69331a0011bc6940?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn89@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-46-091_e35ef20bc14d2c72.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe0f69331a0011bc693c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn8@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-44-847_01b3e914a809397d.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1a6f5b310011724af4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn31@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-56-680_43d765191a462232.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28c58324306a66835be62e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn38@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-813_cce126b537e264a9.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29b2e8b6d52d3a0b11ec26?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn57@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-48-860_fdb517aeff348147.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa03c2069331a0011bc6bb3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn7@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-48-540_75a71ef349309adc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b05f62fa8153517a54b7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn52@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-56-751_878a2522768df050.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28c407b6d52d62983729b3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn33@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-58-001_2071df14ebaf9e9c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1e69331a0011bc6942?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn58@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-55-942_b56c155c292b53dd.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe086f5b310011724af0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-50-046_8bbb19b3d4ad4673.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe126f5b310011724af2?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/5e29afec24306a38ea48c0c5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn89@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-54-315_ccd1c3f79ce09445.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f3af9bea3eafa001de069bd?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn71@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-44-367_28569c8bf6157d68.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29b26824306a3b6d336cf6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn86@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-49-201_e262c792ae448c98.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29af4324306a38695c1686?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn7@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-42-683_5b05b56f300a1b38.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29b18462fa813ed156c455?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn74@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-45-563_103abc0094b153c7.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b2f324306a5232760c36?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn20@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-48-443_e7c06a2840441981.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b27b24306a51b46bc3a2?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-43-518_07e2addca4133ed5.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29a9aa62fa8138277cef42?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/5e29cea3b6d52d5d301c02c4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn78@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-36-547_2185390ef359c283.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa0675e91178a0019b3dc2d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn16@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-44-872_87dbeaeb84e0eccc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28be58b6d52d5c3909c63b?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn80@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-39-181_92057622f4249434.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e41c0ce3b62b73cb139e928?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn81@2020_6/2020/11/03/05-31-57-638_b4b250897a236e16.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b0fcb6d52d4ebc2fc363?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn16@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-40-642_cc13ddcb837c8986.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29c712b6d52d546058e453?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn65@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-48-895_0f2f10c506185c6e.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b47924306a53d91d8f53?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-54-535_77b4554b9b00b355.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b3b224306a530d66c1b4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn94@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-34-618_263f213f5b791b2b.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29aab0b6d52d32b0370f52?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn26@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-50-746_c5cfd877bda6a4c8.webp","https://i.insider.com/5fa0740a91178a0019b3dc86?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn73@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-52-714_3595c378ca751789.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b6b362fa815ae5021ad5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn40@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-38-224_f8ad1c54041eb007.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b14bb6d52d4f500866e5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-45-520_6eba83527d00ff09.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29c29662fa8153de6bd336?format=jpeg":null,"https://i.insider.com/5e41c1af4b661b3da44f0b38?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn99@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-41-568_52b24b91908b8b7c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b34fb6d52d51e045b544?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn62@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-53-218_355792dca89140eb.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e28b6e762fa815b10686093?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn59@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-40-012_c56b6d4937d4a8bf.webp","https://i.insider.com/5e29bd5424306a48ed1aae63?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-42-601_83176ad236789be6.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1d6f5b310011724af7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn48@2020_4/2020/11/03/05-31-54-008_afbc3d0e972abffa.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe096f5b310011724af1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn12@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-37-648_998fd4fc0c616222.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f9dfe1b69331a0011bc693e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_2/2020/11/03/05-31-48-541_4de0d4b01058a869.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn37@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-293_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mWFV-jYr_Oc:fKUqT9Ss14E:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn68@2020_3/2020/11/03/05-31-42-465_a6b5aa3e939b7fe9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mWFV-jYr_Oc:fKUqT9Ss14E:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn67@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-40-002_970cd5f7a4b5bf47.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":null,"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=mWFV-jYr_Oc:fKUqT9Ss14E:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn70@2020_1/2020/11/03/05-31-55-533_054e13f2dc16f9e8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/mWFV-jYr_Oc":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn6@2020_5/2020/11/03/05-31-36-788_6f2b0d44ec926dd0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1604381490541},{"createdTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"A massive hacking network that Microsoft and the US military tried to stop last month is already back — and it could be a bad sign for Election Day","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/trickbot-election-microsoft-botnet-malware-hackers-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5fa01bd36f5b310011724c13?format=jpeg\" alt=\"hacker person keyboard cyber security\" height=\"1332\" width=\"1776\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Thomas Trutschel/Photothek via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Cybercriminals carried out a string of ransomware attacks against US hospitals last week and could be poised to launch even more, US officials warned.</li>\n<li>The FBI said the attacks were carried out in part using Trickbot, a massive network of bots that has for years evaded efforts by security firms and governments to shut it down.</li>\n<li>The wave of attacks last week came after Microsoft announced last month that it majorly disrupted the bot network by working with the US military, taking 94% of its infrastructure offline &#8212; but cybercriminals rebuilt the botnet shortly after, analysts said.</li>\n<li>Cybersecurity experts say the events show the resiliency of ransomware hackers' tactics, and build on longstanding fears that the ransomware could be used to target local elections offices, potentially making it more difficult to count ballots on Election Day.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Last month, Microsoft announced it had won a major victory in the fight against cybercrime. The company <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/microsoft-thwarts-massive-botnet-that-could-have-targeted-elections-2020-10\">said</a> in mid-October that it had thwarted Trickbot — a stubborn malware network that's been used to infect critical computer systems, often shutting them down for ransom. Experts were relieved by the announcement; Trickbot and other ransomware infrastructure, they had warned, could be used to target elections offices and cause chaos on Election Day.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">But less than two weeks later, an unprecedented wave of ransomware attacks hit US hospitals — and US officials and cybersecurity experts said Trickbot's makers were to blame.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The FBI said in a <a href=\"https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-302a\">warning</a> that cybercriminals used Trickbot in conjunction with other viruses to carry out <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/hospitals-across-the-us-hit-with-ransomware-attacks-fbi-warns-2020-10\">a wave of attacks against US hospitals</a> last week, disrupting their computer systems and delaying surgeries. More attacks carried out by the same group could be looming, US officials added.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The wave of ransomware attacks show that the cybercriminals who built Trickbot are undeterred and quickly adapting new tools to carry out similar attacks, according to Jeremy Kennelly, analysis manager at FireEye's Mandiant Threat Intelligence unit, which has been tracking the group's botnet activity.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Microsoft is now locked in a cat-and-mouse game with the makers of Trickbot, who quickly rebuilt the botnet but used other strains of malware in their arsenal to attack hospitals last week, Kennelly says. In those attacks, Trickbot makers deployed malware on behalf of other cybercriminals like the Russian speaking hacker group UNC 1878, according to security analysts and US officials.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Security experts told Business Insider that the hackers' tenacity is a sign that their operations are unlikely to be completely thwarted by Election Day. It's is also another sign that hackers and their malware have grown more formidable, even against security giants like Microsoft.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"Microsoft's disruption of the TrickBot botnet was highly successful, however there was evidence shortly thereafter suggesting that the botnet was quickly rebuilt. Despite this back and forth, it appears as though there are ongoing attempts to disrupt the TrickBot botnet's infrastructure which are proving successful, at least for the time being,\" Kennelly told Business Insider, adding that it's unknown whether Microsoft is behind the latest efforts.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Microsoft did not provide an on-the-record statement in response to Business Insider's request for comment. We will update this article if that changes.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The resurgence of the group that made Trickbot raises concerns about Election Day — experts have long warned that ransomware could be used against local elections offices to cause chaos on Election Day, and Microsoft explicitly <a href=\"https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2020/10/20/trickbot-ransomware-disruption-update/\">said</a> that it aimed to disrupt Trickbot near to the election to fend off such attacks. The US Military's Cyber Command also assisted with the effort specifically to protect voting systems from Trickbot, <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/cyber-command-trickbot-disrupt/2020/10/09/19587aae-0a32-11eb-a166-dc429b380d10_story.html\">The Washington Post</a> reported.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"Our disruption is intended to disable Trickbot's infrastructure and make it difficult for its operators to enable ransomware attacks, which have been identified as one of the biggest threats to the upcoming U.S. elections,\" Microsoft VP for security Tom Burt said in a <a href=\"https://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2020/10/20/trickbot-ransomware-disruption-update/\">blog post</a> last month, claiming that Microsoft disabled 94% of Trickbot's infrastructure globally.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Burt also warned that even if Trickbot is handicapped, the botnet's developers could quickly find other tactics, noting that \"there is not always a straight line to success.\"</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Some cybersecurity experts questioned whether Microsoft's announcement on disrupting Trickbot overstated their success at neutralizing the cybercriminals behind the bot network.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"The Trickbot disruption efforts looked more like a PR stunt rather than a takedown operation. By now it's pretty clear to everyone that Trickbot is not going away anytime soon,\" Stefan Tanase, a cybercrime analyst, told Business Insider.<a href=\"https://twitter.com/stefant\" data-focusable=\"true\"></a></p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Other experts say they believe Microsoft's disruption of Trickbot was effective, but that the recent surge in attacks shows hackers' resourcefulness in evading such crackdowns. The FBI <a href=\"https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-302a\">said</a> cybercriminals behind the recent attacks on US hospitals used Trickbot in conjunction with a strain of ransomware called Ryuk and a different botnet called BazarLoader, which could ultimately replace long-established botnets like Trickbot.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"There is no doubt that the actions by Microsoft and US Cyber Command significantly disrupted Trickbot. The series of attacks on hospitals may have been the result of old and previously unexploded ordnance being detonated via Trickbot's&#160;remaining&#160;<wbr>infrastructure,\" Brett Callow, a researcher with the cybersecurity firm Emsisoft, told Business Insider.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Hacker groups could also be retaliating against the attempted Trickbot takedown by Microsoft and the US government, according to Caleb Barlow, CEO of the security firm CynergisTek.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"The timing of this threat raises many eyebrows, occurring just two weeks after an attempted takedown of TrickBot by the U.S. government and Microsoft and less than a week out from the Presidential election,\" Barlow said via email. \"TrickBot may have been significantly disrupted but it is also clearly resilient.\"</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">These experts and others say they see ransomware as an Election Day threat because they could be used to cause chaos or force local governments to pay hefty ransoms.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The ransomware works by handicapping victims' computer systems to extort them. Cybercriminals send their victims phishing links that appear to be trustworthy in order to get their login credentials; from there, they break into an organizations' computer systems and install the ransomware, which locks down the systems until victims pay a ransom.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">There's no indication that hackers would be able to alter vote tallies with the ransomware; rather, cyberattacks could disrupt local elections offices' administrative processes to slow the counting of ballots or make it harder for officials to announce the results of elections. US officials <a href=\"https://apnews.com/article/donald-trump-iran-media-social-media-elections-8cccec2bd393098f9fb39b955ae52bde\">said</a> last month that Russian hackers have targeted local elections offices, stealing voter data from at least two servers, possibly with the intent of disrupting their operations.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The recent string of ransomware attacks appear to be purely profit-motivated, experts said, but cybercriminals may see voting systems on Election Day as a highly profitable target given their crucial function.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\"The ransomware business is all about putting pressure on the victim to pay. The more critical the target is, the easier it is for cybercriminals to extort money,\" Tanase said.<a href=\"https://twitter.com/stefant\" data-focusable=\"true\"></a></p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ransomware attacks have risen by 50% over the past three months, according to security firm Check Point, and experts say ransomware attacks will continue to proliferate as long as victims keep paying ransoms. Some firms have <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/ransomware-attacks-us-treasury-hackers-covid-2020-10\">called on lawmakers to ban ransom payments</a> in order to choke out incentives for criminals.</p><p style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><em><strong>Updated Nov. 2, 2019 at 7:16 p.m.: </strong>This story was updated to include new details from security analysts about Microsoft's fight against Trickbot's makers.</em>&#160;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/trickbot-election-microsoft-botnet-malware-hackers-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a 2020 20:29:30 13:31:30","updatedTime":"2020-11-03 13:31:30","title":"Twitter labels Trump's tweet about the Supreme Court's ruling on Pennsylvania mail-in ballots as misleading and blocks users from sharing and liking","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-trump-tweet-supreme-court-pennsylvania-mail-in-ballots-misleading-2020-11","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f8661f0fd1f49001964d7b5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"trump twitter\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rafael Henrique/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Twitter on Monday labeled a Trump tweet about mail-in voting as making a \"potentially misleading claim about an election,\" and banned users from liking or sharing it.</li>\n<li>Trump's tweet claimed without evidence that a recent Supreme Court ruling &#8212; allowing Pennsylvania to count mail-in ballots that arrive up to three days after Election Day &#8212; would lead to widespread election fraud.</li>\n<li>A Twitter spokesperson said the tweet violated the platform's \"<a href=\"https://help.twitter.com/en/rules-and-policies/election-integrity-policy\">civic integrity</a>\" policy and that it would \"significantly restrict engagements\" with the tweet.</li>\n<li>Trump has repeatedly attempted to cast doubt on mail-in voting, but fact-checkers and election experts have consistently found virtually no evidence of fraud connected with the voting method, which has been used for years.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Twitter on the eve of Election Day, labeled yet another <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump\">tweet from President Donald Trump</a> for violating its policies against spreading election-related misinformation and prevented users from sharing or liking the tweet.</p><p>Trump <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1323430341512622080\">tweeted</a> Monday evening — without evidence — that a recent decision by the US Supreme Court to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/supreme-court-rules-pennsylvania-can-extend-mail-in-receipt-deadline-2020-10?r=ts-sub\">allow Pennsylvania to count mail-in ballots</a> received up to three days after Election Day would lead to widespread election fraud and violence.</p><p>The state's Supreme Court had extended the deadline in response to the coronavirus pandemic and postal delays, and the US Supreme Court did not approve a request from Republican state officials to block the extension. The ruling requires county election officials to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/scotus-decision-on-pennsylvania-ballots-is-one-of-most-important-in-2020-2020-10\">count ballots that arrive by November 6</a>, as long as there's no evidence they were mailed after the polls closed on November 3, even if their postmarks were illegible or missing.</p><p>\"The Supreme Court decision on voting in Pennsylvania is a VERY dangerous one,\" Trump tweeted, without evidence. \"It will allow rampant and unchecked cheating and will undermine our entire systems of laws. It will also induce violence in the streets. Something must be done!\"</p><p>There is no evidence that the ruling will lead to increased voter fraud, violence, or upend the US legal system. Election results are never finalized on election night, and it's a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-hopes-states-wont-allowed-count-ballots-after-election-day-2020-10\">normal part of the electoral process</a> for ballots to be counted days or even weeks after voters go to the polls.&#160;</p><p>\"We placed a warning on [Trump's tweet] for making a potentially misleading claim about an election,\" a Twitter spokesperson told Business Insider. \"This action is in line with our <a href=\"https://help.twitter.com/en/rules-and-policies/election-integrity-policy\">Civic Integrity Policy</a>, and as is standard with this warning, we will significantly restrict engagements on this Tweet.\"</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Donald J. Trump  (@realDonaldTrump) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1323430341512622080?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 3, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>This is not the first time Twitter has slapped a warning on one of Trump's tweets about mail-in voting. The platform took action on a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-trump-tweet-mail-voting-warning-label-minsinformation-block-retweet-2020-10\">misleading Trump tweet last week</a>, also falsely claiming all ballots must be counted by Election Day and has applied fact checks on multiple occasions since <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/twitters-first-fact-check-on-trumps-voting-tweets-was-misleading-2020-5\">first doing so in May</a>.</p><p>In the months leading up to the election, Trump has ratcheted up his attacks on mail-in voting and other standard and legitimate aspects of the electoral process, without evidence, and at times <a href=\"https://www.texastribune.org/2020/10/29/texas-dan-patrick-elections-voting/\">echoed by prominent Republicans</a>.</p><p>Historically, election experts have found that all voter fraud, including <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-states-require-to-verify-absentee-ballots-prevent-fraud-map-2020-10\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"40\" data-uri=\"805f7b28d41a7117b20b701aaa079150\">mail-in voter fraud, is exceedingly rare</a>.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a Donald Trump is closing out his 2020 reelection campaign by attacking celebrities who've backed his opponent.&#160;</li>\n<li>Trump on Monday went after Lady Gaga and Jon Bon Jovi at an event in Pennsylvania, a crucial battleground state.</li>\n<li>\"Jon Bon Jovi: Every time I see him, he kisses my a--,\" Trump said.</li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>With millions of Americans unemployed and more than 231,000 dead from COVID-19 as cases rise across the country, President Donald Trump's closing message to voters on the eve of Election Day was centered on personal grievances and attacking celebrities who've thrown their support behind former Vice President Joe Biden.&#160;</p><p>At a rally in Avoca, Pennsylvania, on Monday, Trump targeted Lady Gaga and Jon Bon Jovi.&#160;</p><p>\"Now he's got Lady Gaga — Lady Gaga. It's not too good. I could tell you plenty of stories. I could tell you stories about Lady Gaga. I know a lot of stories — Lady Gaga. And Jon Bon Jovi: Every time I see him, he kisses my a--,\" Trump said, prompting laughter from the audience.&#160;</p><p><em><strong>Read more</strong>: <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/kimberly-guilfoyle-don-jr-president-trump-fox-news-2020-10?r=oo-kush\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\" data-qa=\"message_attachment_title_link\">How Kimberly Guilfoyle, the 'human Venus flytrap,' has groomed boyfriend Donald Trump Jr. into a political powerhouse and turned herself into a conservative star</a></em></p><p>The president discussed multiple celebrities and their support for Democrats during the Avoca rally, including Beyoncé, Jay-Z, and LeBron James.&#160;</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;The Recount  (@therecount) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1323364312027697153?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 2, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">&#8212;Aaron Rupar  (@atrupar) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1323363186188427264?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">November 2, 2020</a></blockquote><script async src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p>Bon Jovi in late October <a href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/uk-factcheck-bon-jovi-biden/fact-check-bon-jovi-did-not-play-in-front-of-just-12-people-and-7-pumpkins-at-a-biden-campaign-event-idUSKBN27B2EG\">performed at a drive-in rally for Biden</a> and his vice-presidential running mate, Sen. Kamala Harris, in Dallas, Pennsylvania. Lady Gaga was set to perform at a drive-in rally for the Democratic presidential nominee <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ladygaga/status/1323021701945446401?s=20\">in Pittsburgh on Monday night</a>.</p><p>The Trump campaign has lashed out at Lady Gaga, in particular, in recent days.</p><p>Tim Murtaugh, the Trump campaign's communications director, on Sunday <a href=\"https://twitter.com/TimMurtaugh/status/1323009227695263748\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tweeted</a>: \"Nothing exposes Biden's disdain for the forgotten working men &#38; women of PA like campaigning with anti-fracking activist Lady Gaga. This desperate effort to drum up enthusiasm is actually a sharp stick in the eye for 600,000 Pennsylvanians who work in the fracking industry.\"</p><p>The president echoed this message in an early-morning tweet on Monday, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1323155809682051073?s=20\">saying</a>: \"Just learned that Sleepy Joe Biden is campaigning in Pennsylvania with Lady Gaga, a proud member of 'Artists Against Fracking.'\"</p><p>Trump has repeatedly and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-biden-policy-positions-most-important-election-issues-2020-9\">falsely claimed</a> that Biden wants to ban fracking.</p><p>In response to Murtaugh's tweet, <a href=\"https://twitter.com/ladygaga/status/1323040269852397568?s=20\">Lady Gaga tweeted</a>: \"HEY TIM HEY @realDonaldTrump SO HAPPY IM GLAD TO BE LIVING RENT FREE in your HEAD. #BidenHarris.\"</p><p>Trump is trailing Biden in the national polls, and the former vice president also has a lead over the president in Pennsylvania. The state, where 20 electoral votes are up for grabs, is seen as crucial by both campaigns in terms of their pathways to victory.</p><p>The president won in Pennsylvania by less than 1 percentage point in 2016.</p><p>On Monday, Biden led Trump by <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/where-biden-trump-stand-polls-one-day-out-election-day-2020-11\">about 5 percentage points</a> in Pennsylvania, according to FiveThirtyEight's updating average.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/trump-rants-about-lady-gaga-jon-bon-jovi-election-eve-2020-11'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eCgJZShE6zA:9-lzvmwVn8Q:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eCgJZShE6zA:9-lzvmwVn8Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eCgJZShE6zA:9-lzvmwVn8Q:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"
